Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: International collaboration to advance biomanufacturing; September 7-8, 2017; Brussels, Belgium

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Industrial biotechnology and biomanufacturing have the potential to benefit from advances in basic research and technology such as synthetic biology, cell free synthesis and nanomanufacturing. However, leveraging advances in basic science such that they have an economic impact has been slower in the area of biomanufacturing than in some other manufacturing areas. This is in part due to the challenges of engineering biology, where processes such as evolution and adaptation ensure the survival of species in their native environment, but hinder the development of robust, reproducible processes within bioreactors. The workshop will bring together leaders in the field from the US and Europe to address these challenges. The results of the workshop will be disseminated broadly. In addition, this meeting will provide the foundation for international collaborations between researchers in the US and Europe in the area of biomanufacturing.

In order to address the challenges associated with translating advances in synthetic biology, cell free synthesis, nanomanufacturing and other areas of basic science into advances in biomanufacturing, this international workshop will be convened, with joint support from the National Science Foundation and the European Commission. The workshop will bring together leaders in the field from both sides of the Atlantic to: (1) Explore and identify areas of joint interests, needs, and opportunities associated with the translation of basic research advances in areas such as synthetic biology, cell free synthesis and nanomanufacturing (the engineering of biology) into advances in biomanufacturing and industrial biotechnology such that they have economic impact; (2) Identify research questions that could address translational potential of new technologies; (3) Explore the educational needs to ensure a well-trained and responsible workforce in the area; and (4) Assess the need for collaboration on issues such as standards and repositories, and cyberinfrastructure, as well ethical and societal concerns on an international scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Workshop report: EU-US High Level Expert Meeting on Biotechnology

18 - 19 April 2018, Offices of the European Commission

Brussels, Belgium

 

Given the increasing global nature of science, exchanges between leading researchers from different areas of the world are becoming increasingly important. Earlier this year, a group of 23 US and European scientists and engineers who work in areas of basic research and advanced biomanufacturing participated in a workshop held at the Offices of the European Commission to identify opportunities for international collaboration that would help speed the application of basic research in fields of synthetic biology, nanomanufacturing, and cell free biomanufacturing.   

 

The program was organized into four topical areas: (i) Emerging technologies that could advance industrial biotechnology, biomanufacturing, and cell free biomanufacturing; (ii) Innovations in biomanufacturing that could improve robustness, accelerate bringing products to the market or change bioprocessing paradigms; (iii) Need for collaboration on standards, repositories, and cyberinfrastructure, as well as ethical and societal concerns on an international scale; and (iv) The scientific challenges of biomanufacturing and the training of a new generation of biotechnologists.

 

Meeting attendees were partitioned into four groups, each charged with leading discussion of a topical area.

 

Topic 1 addressed the “rules of life” and the need to understand life’s basic components and the ways in which they are stitched together. Cell free systems enable thought provoking hypotheses and rules discovery. There was great enthusiasm for collaborative work and the creation of testbeds that would enable new vantage points for the Design-Build-Test-Learn cycle. A completely bottom up approach was envisioned for creating a cell comprised of an essential and minimal number of parts.

 

In Topic 2, the group examined gaps between traditional roles of academia and industry, referring to Technology Readiness Levels (TRL). The NSF has a substantial effort at bridging this gap, primarily through the NSF Industry-University Cooperative Research Centers (IUCRC) program. The US NNMI program targets similar technology and manufacturing gaps. The EU BBI JU program similarly brings together academia, industry and government to make advances in biomanufacturing. The group proposed a transdisciplinary academia/industry/government partnership to identify “tools” (e.g., synthetic biology, systems biology, etc.) that could be cross referenced against “applications areas” (e.g., biopharmaceuticals, industrial enzymes, etc.) and relevant experts could be identified to exchange knowledge regarding industry problems and academic-led solutions. A vision for sustainability was widely embraced as an additional avenue for commercialization beyond the often-cited healthcare sector.

 

Topic 3 dealt largely with standards, repositories, and infrastructure that are needed to make most efficient use of research resources. In addition to actual repositories, the need for consistent terminology, robust modeling methodologies, and standardized analytical measurements were viewed as necessary components of any viable path forward. An upcoming Horizon2020 project is focused on standards. That said, while there is a need to create convergence, there was also the recognition that concordance need not be uniform. To avoid “paralysis of perfection”, standards creation should include individuals expert in standards, likely from other fields.

 

Several educational programs that break down barriers were discussed as models in Topic 4, including MIT’s NEET initiative. Pedagogical models are needed that enable students to think “outside the box” by challenging them with open-ended problems that stimulate “data gathering” and that lead to “data distillation” and proposed solutions grounded in discipline-specific first principles. There is a tendency for students to use social media and www to mine information, rather than hone one’s discriminatory ability to discern factual, relevant information from irrelevant and false information.

 

In summary, exciting pathways that embrace bottom-up approaches (e.g., artificial cell and cell-free systems) for discovery and product synthesis were highlighted along with educational programs that stimulate creativity while at the same time reinforce first principles. Motivations beyond healthcare, including sustainability, were advanced, as were “hybrid” methodologies that combine biological with abiological components. A sustained effort to link an excited, trusted-respected, knowledgeable community of academic and industrial PIs was envisioned and proposed. A public private partnership (PPP) that develops a broad, motivational vision (e.g., including value-chain, systematic thinking, conceptual designs, predictable performance across scales) was seen as a short term objective. This could be supported by the NSF RCN program. Importantly, October 2018 brings the 20-year celebration of signing of the EU-US treaty on scientific cooperation. This was viewed as an excellent opportunity to capitalize on momentum created in Brussels.
